entry.title: Punishment for Kenyan gang rapists lifted from cutting grass to 15 years' jail
entry.summary: Rape is a serious problem in Kenya but is seldom taken seriously by the police, rights groups say.

entry.title: Reeling from attack, Christians attend emotional Easter services at church in Garissa, Kenya
Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary:
A woman gestures after she viewed the body of a relative killed in Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

A mother, second right, grieves after discovering her son was amongst those killed, as she leaves a center set up for relatives and survivors in Garissa, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya 'open-minded' on appeal to increase Jeptoo ban
Kenyan police say suspect caught surveilling president home
entry.summary: Kenya security forces have increased the frequency of arrests of people suspected of involvement in extremism since four gunmen from the Somali extremist group al-Shabab killed 148 people earlier this month at a college in Garissa, Kenya.

entry.title: Kenyan police say suspect caught surveilling president home
entry.summary: Prosecutor Daniel Karuri told a court Wednesday that police require more time to interrogate Said Mire Siyad, who was found in the presidents home in Gatundu South in central Kenya.

entry.title: Kenya: 9 security chiefs suspended over al-Shabab attack
Grief counselors on hand to help families after Kenya attack
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - There was sobbing and silent grief.

entry.title: Kenya official compares Garissa University terror victims to 'cockroaches'
Christian students at Kenya's Garissa University foretold massacre
entry.summary: Kitengela, Kenya: As Stanley Muli hid in a wardrobe from attacking Somali militants last week, he wondered why the army was taking so long to arrive.

entry.title: Kenya massacre victims were lined up and shot as they phoned parents
entry.summary:
Maureen Manyengo, a 21-year-old Christian from western Kenya, who was training to be a teacher, described how she hid inside her wardrobe after seeing several friends killed.

So far, 147 people have been confirmed dead and 79 injured in Kenya's worst terrorist attack in two decades, but officials have admitted that the number killed could rise as piles of bodies are recounted.

Joseph Nkaissery, Kenya's interior minister, confirmed that the gunmen had been strapped with explosives and blew up "like bombs" as they were shot by a special forces squad.

entry.title: One killed, 150 hurt in Kenya stampede after power cable blast
Gunman in Kenya university massacre ID'd as son of official
entry.summary:
Hundreds of Kenyan youths have trained with Al Shabab and then returned to Kenya, posing a major security threat, according to former police chief Mathew Iteere.

Police waited seven hours before sending a special tactical unit into the college to fight the gunmen, Kenya's Daily Nation newspaper reported Sunday.

Kenya's government has said another source of instability is the country's refugee camps, with more than 423,000 Somali refugees.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory to deter elephant poachers
entry.summary:
A Kenya Wildlife Services officer stands near a burning pile of 15 tonnes of elephant ivory seized in Kenya.

Nairobi:Kenya has burned 15 tonnes of elephant tusks and rhino horns as part of efforts to curb poaching of the mammals in the East African country.

Poachers killed 164 elephants in Kenya last year, compared with 302 in 2013 and 384 in 2012, while 53 rhinos were killed in 2014 compared with 59 and 30 in the previous two years, according to the Kenya Wildlife Service.

"This shows we are committed to save our elephants and we want the world to know that ivory belongs to the elephants," Paul Udoto, spokesman for the Kenya Wildlife Service, said at the ceremony.

Kenya may have as much as 100 tonnes of contraband ivory in its stockpiles, according to Paula Kahumba, chief executive officer of WildlifeDirect, a Nairobi-based non-governmental conservation organisation.

entry.title: U.N. refugee chief to visit Kenya to plan return of Somali refugees
Community radio brings forecasts to Kenyaâ€™s most climate vulnerable
entry.summary:
Nganyi RANET - it stands for "Radio Internet" - is a community radio station set up by the Kenya Meteorological Service to target communities particularly vulnerable to climate extremes.

There are now five RANET radio stations in Kenya where the climate change impacts are particularly strong.

entry.title: Kenya shuts down Somali remittance firms
entry.summary: Somalia's central bank governor Bashir Issa Ali told Reuters that 13 Somali money transfer firms have been officially notified by Central Bank of Kenya (CBK) about the closure of accounts.

entry.title: Kenya seeks more Western help after university attack
entry.summary: Mohamed said Kenya was looking at ways it can put up more border posts and improve surveillance along the frontier, an area where foreign allies may be able to help.

entry.title: Kenya massacre victims were lined up and shot as they phoned parents
entry.summary:
The gunmen, from the Somali Islamist terrorist group al-Shabaab, stormed Garissa University in north-east Kenya.

Peter Aling'o, senior researcher with the Institute for Security Studies in Nairobi, said al-Shabaab was taking advantage of "gaps" in Kenya's intelligence-led security planning.

entry.title: Ethiopia?s Desisa, Kenya?s Rotich winners at Boston Marathon
Kenya Official: I Did Not Cause Delay in Ending Attack
entry.summary: On the day of the attack the helicopter had taken a police commander to northern Kenya and the plane had gone to Mombasa for a training exercise.

entry.title: Pope pleas to Kenya university gunmen to 'come to their senses'
entry.summary: He urged the visiting bishops to work with Christian and non-Christian leaders to promote peace in predominantly-Christian Kenya.

entry.title: Activists criticise Kenya for putting Muslim groups on Shabaab supporters' list
UN Urges Kenya to Reconsider Demand to Shut Refugee Camp
entry.summary: The agency is urging Nairobi to give the matter further consideration, she said, adding that it is ready to intensify work with Kenya to strengthen law enforcement at Dadaab.

entry.title: UN urges Kenya to reconsider demand to shut refugee camp
entry.summary: The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees is concerned that abruptly shutting Dadaab and forcing the refugees back to Somalia "would have extreme humanitarian and practical consequences, and would be a breach of Kenya's international obligations," spokeswoman Karin de Gruijl said in Geneva.

entry.title: UN urges Kenya to reconsider demand to shut refugee camp
entry.summary:
BERLIN (AP) " The United Nations' refugee agency urged Kenya on Tuesday to reconsider its demand for the closure of a vast camp for Somali refugees within three months.

Kenyan Deputy President William Ruto made the demand Saturday, urging the agency to send the more than 400,000 refugees living at the Dadaab camp back home or see Kenya relocate them itself.

entry.title: Athletics-Two agents suspended by Athletics Kenya in doping probe
entry.summary: Kiplagat said Athletics Kenya would work with the international athletics body, the IAAF, and would meet promoters of the Diamond League to agree on how to manage athletes handled by the two agencies to ensure they did not miss competitions.

entry.title: Athletics Kenya bans agents of Dennis Kimetto pending doping investigations
entry.summary: Kenya's athletics federation has suspended the agents of marathon world record holder Dennis Kimetto and other top stars while it investigates the spike in doping among the country's runners.

entry.title: Kenya 'grass cutter' gang rapists jailed for 15 years
entry.summary: "While Kenya boasts one of the most progressive legal and policy frameworks for addressing sexual violence, Liz's case and countless others have revealed significant failures of local authorities to adequately address sexual violence."

entry.title: Punishment for Kenyan gang rapists lifted from cutting grass to 15 years' jail
entry.summary: The then 16-year-old victim, known by the pseudonym Liz, was reportedly attacked, beaten and then raped by six men as she returned from her grandfather's funeral in western Kenya in June, 2013.

entry.title: Kenya asks the UN to shut down refugee camp for Somalis
entry.summary: "We have asked the UNHCR to relocate the refugees in three months, failure to which we shall relocate them ourselves. The way America changed after 9/11 is the way Kenya will change after Garissa," Ruto said in a statement distributed by his press office.

entry.title: One killed, 150 hurt in Kenya stampede after power cable blast
entry.summary:
Kenya has responded by asking the UN refugee agency to repatriate hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees by July, a move criticised by the UN refugee agency and rights groups.

In another response, Kenya also last week shut down 14 money transfer companies -- vital for impoverished Somalia -- over their suspected links to Shebab.

entry.title: Terror scare prompts deadly Kenya stampede
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - One Kenyan student was killed and 141 injured in a stampede Sunday on the campus of the University of Nairobi when students mistook several accidental explosions for an extremist attack, according to an official.

entry.title: Kenya orders UN to move massive Somali refugee camp
entry.summary: The complex of camps hosts more than 600,000 Somali refugees, according to Ruto, in a remote, dry corner in northeast Kenya, about an hour's drive from Garissa town.

entry.title: Kenya demands UN move massive Dadaab refugee camp across border to Somalia
entry.summary:
Kenya has given the United Nations three months to remove a camp housing more than half a million Somali refugees, as part of a get-tough response to the killing of 148 people by Somali gunmen at a Kenyan university.

"The way America changed after 9/11 is the way Kenya will change after Garissa," he said, referring to the university that was attacked on April 2.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for officer who helped stop attack
entry.summary: Transparency International has ranked the police as Kenya's most corrupt institution.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for police officer who helped stop extremist that killed 148
entry.summary: The success of Recce Company has given a much needed boost to the image of the Kenya police force, which many deride as ineffective and corrupt.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's Burial for Officer Who Helped Stop Attack
entry.summary: Most walked for several kilometres (miles) on dusty paths to the remote village in southwestern Kenya, others arrived in bicycle taxis, the privileged in cars and even helicopters.

entry.title: Kenya demands UN removes massive Somali refugee camp
entry.summary:
Kenya has in the past accused Islamist militants of hiding out in Dadaab camp which it now wants the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR to move across the border to inside Somalia.

Ruto said Kenya had started building a 700-km (440-mile) wall along the entire length of the border with Somalia to keep out members of the Somali Islamist militant group al Shabaab.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for officer who helped stop attack
entry.summary: Thousands have gathered in a remote village in Kenya's Rift Valley to give a hero's burial to a police officer who died fighting to end an Islamic extremist attack on a university which killed 148 people.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for officer who helped stop attack
entry.summary: Corporal Benard Kipkemoi Tonui was part of the police department's Recce Company which stopped the April 2 attack on Garissa University College in eastern Kenya in less than half an hour.

entry.title: Grief counselors on hand to help families after Kenya attack
Grief counselors on hand to help families after Kenya attack
entry.summary: A small army of counselors, many in Kenya Red Cross vests, were deployed to the Chiromo Funeral Parlour to lend support after the attack by al-Shabab, a Somalia-based extremist group that killed 148 people.

entry.title: After attack and backlash, Kenya faces battle to win over Muslims
entry.summary:
Without the cooperation of local people like Bare, experts say Kenya will struggle to glean vital on-the-ground intelligence to stop crude but highly lethal assaults by Somalia's al Shabaab militants.

Winning favour with Muslim communities near Somalia has been made more urgent by al Shabaab's switch in tactics to target Kenya's frontier regions near the porous 700km border.

Kenyan Defence Forces (KDF) spokesman David Obonyo denied the troops had a track record of brutality against Muslims, who make up about 10 percent of Kenya's 44 million people.

But to get Muslims on board, especially the 2.4 million ethnic Somalis living in Kenya, the authorities will have to address their deep suspicion of the security services.

entry.title: Unsung heroes: Kenya counselors help relatives of the dead
entry.summary: "You have to be there," whether it means embracing a grieving parent, talking or just being present without saying anything, said Sammy Mwangi, a worker with the Kenya Red Cross.

entry.title: Unsung heroes: Kenya counselors help relatives of the dead
Kenya freezes key money transfers to Somalia after university terror attack
entry.summary:
Kenya has frozen key money transfer companies vital for Somalia after the police chief issued a list of 85 people and businesses with suspected links to the Al-Qaeda-linked group al-Shabab.

Their suspension in Kenya would have major impact on money transfers, with aid agencies warning in the past their suspension would hit some of poorest people the hardest.

The notice, issued under Kenya's prevention of terrorism act and which gives the names listed 24 hours to demonstrate why they "should not be declared a specified entity," was signed by Kenya's police chief Joseph Boinett.

entry.title: Kenya freezes assets suspected of funding Islamic extremists
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - A senior Kenyan official says the government is freezing assets of dozens of organizations and individuals that he said are suspected of financing Islamic extremist activities.

entry.title: Kenya freezes assets of groups and individuals suspected of funding Islamic extremists
Kenya shuts money transfer firms
Kenyan students demonstrate to honor attack victims - VIDEO: Kenya starts airstrikes against Al-Shabaab - VIDEO: Al-Shabaab in Somalia a threat to US?
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - Hundreds of Kenyan students marched through downtown Nairobi on Tuesday to honor those who died in an attack on a college by Islamic militants and to press the government for better security in the wake of the slaughter.

entry.title: Kenya attack victims had big plans for life
entry.summary: An unidentified relative, center-right, grieves after identifying the body of one of those killed in the attack in Garissa, at the Chiromo Funeral Parlour in Nairobi, Kenya Monday, April 6, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya attack victims had big plans for life
entry.summary: But Bryson Mwakuleghwa, a 21-year-old student at Garissa University College in Kenya, never had the chance to make his dreams happen.

entry.title: Kenya attack victims had big plans for life
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - He was a soccer player with a fighting spirit, a talented keyboard player with "golden fingers" who was intent on succeeding in life, his guardian said.

entry.title: News24.com | Pope calls on world to defend modern Christian martyrs
entry.summary: The Vatican's official preacher, Father Raniero Cantalamessa, said on Friday there was a "disturbing indifference" among world institutions and in public opinion to the killing of Christians, mentioning the bloodshed in Kenya and Libya.

entry.title: Kenya destroys 2 al Shabaab camps in Somalia
entry.summary: The mission was part of efforts to stop al Shabaab fighters from those camps carrying out cross-border raids into Kenya, Obonyo said.

entry.title: Kenya says destroys 2 al Shabaab camps in Somalia
entry.summary:
Jets pounded the camps in the Gedo region on the other side of the border on Sunday, Kenya Defence Forces spokesman David Obonyo said.

Kenya has struggled to stop the flow of militants and weapons across its 700 km (450 mile) border with Somalia, and the violence has also damaged the economy by scaring away tourists and investors.

entry.title: Kenya bombs al Shabaab camps in Somalia - military source
entry.summary: "The U.S. used to have many soldiers in Somalia but it recalled them. Kenya should also remove its military officers from Somalia," Odinga said on Sunday, according to comments in Monday's edition of Kenya's Standard newspaper.

entry.title: Kenya bombs al-Shabab camps in Somalia after Garissa attack
entry.summary: Kenya has so far shown no inclination to pull out of Somalia where its troops, part of a UN-backed African Union peacekeeping mission, have wrestled swathes of territory from the Islamist group.

entry.title: Kenya launches air strikes against Al Shabab camps
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya launched air strikes against Islamic militants in Somalia following an extremist attack on a Kenyan college that killed 148 people, a military spokesman said Monday.

entry.title: Kenya bombed two al Shabaab camps in Somalia on Sunday - military source
entry.summary: "We targeted the two areas because according to information we have, those (al Shabaab) fellows are coming from there to attack Kenya," he said, in reference to Thursday's massacre at Garissa University College, some 200km (120 miles) from the Somali border.

entry.title: Al-Shabaab camps bombed in retaliation by Kenyan air force
entry.summary: The Kenyan air force bombed two al-Shabaab camps in Somalia on Sunday, a Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) source said, in the first major military response to last week's attack by the militant group on a Kenyan university.

entry.title: Kenya bombed al Shabaab camps in Somalia on Sunday: military source
entry.summary:
Jets pounded the camps in Gondodowe and Ismail, both in the Gedo region bordering Kenya, the military source said on Monday.

"We targeted the two areas because according to information we have, those (al Shabaab) fellows are coming from there to attack Kenya," he said.

entry.title: Law graduate named as Kenya university massacre killer
entry.summary: Kenyatta is under heavy pressure to halt Islamist attacks that have ravaged Kenya's tourist industry and the Daily Nation newspaper questioned in an editorial why it took nearly 15 hours to end the siege.

entry.title: Law graduate named as Kenya university massacre killer
entry.summary: Militant attacks on Christians have damaged Kenya's traditionally cordial Christian-Muslim relations, and priests said they feared churches could be targeted on the main liturgical feast in the Christian calendar.

entry.title: Law graduate named as Kenya university massacre killer
entry.summary: Ali Roba, the governor of Mandera county, said Kenya had "massive radicalisation problems, not only in the northern counties, but across the country."

entry.title: Law graduate named as Kenya massacre killer as country mourns
entry.summary:
The massacre, Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, claimed the lives of 142 students, three police officers and three soldiers.

"Kenya is at war, and we must all stand together," said Naado, the deputy head of the Supreme Council of Kenya Muslims, saying the organisation was helping to raise money for the funerals of those killed and the medical costs of the scores of wounded.

entry.title: Kenya says government official's son was among gunmen in Garissa attack
entry.summary: "It...beggars belief that many of the failures that were witnessed during the Westgate siege - including the late deployment of specialised police - were repeated in Garissa," Kenya's biggest-selling said.

entry.title: Gunman a ?brilliant upcoming lawyer?
entry.summary: AUTHORITIES in Kenya say they have identified one of the four dead al-Shabab gunmen who massacred nearly 150 people at Garissa University as an ethnic-Somali Kenyan national and law graduate.

entry.title: Kenya massacre gunman was son of government official
entry.summary: To prevent an escalation of Islamic radicalization in Kenya, it is important that parents inform authorities if their children go missing or show tendencies of following violent extremism, said Njoka.

entry.title: Kenya says son of a government official was among gunmen in Garissa attack
entry.summary:
The Garissa assault has further strained the historically cordial relations between Kenya's Christian and Muslim communities, which have deteriorated due to frequent Islamist attacks on Christian priests and churches.

A dusk-to-dawn curfew is in force along Kenya's 700km border with Somalia and helicopters monitor its palm-fringed coast, popular with Western tourists and the scene of Islamist attacks in the past.

entry.title: Pope Francis prays for Kenya students, decries persecution
entry.summary: Pope Francis prayed for an end to the persecution of Christians in his Easter Sunday address, commemorating the students massacred by Islamist militants at Garissa University in Kenya.

entry.title: Pope Francis prays for Kenya students, decries persecution
entry.summary: "May constant prayer rise up from all people of goodwill for those who lost their lives - I think in particular of the young people who were killed last Thursday at Garissa University College in Kenya - for all who have been kidnapped, and for those forced to abandon their homes and their dear ones."

entry.title: Kenya police: 1 gunman identified in attack that killed 148
After Islamist attack, armed guards shield Kenyan churches
entry.summary: GARISSA, Kenya (Reuters) - Kenyan churches used armed guards to protect their Easter congregations on Sunday, days after gunmen from the Islamist al Shabaab group killed nearly 150 people at a Kenyan university.

entry.title: Prayers, fear mark Easter services in Garissa, Kenya
Kenya's Easter prayers mark start of official mourning for university attacks
entry.summary: Earlier on Saturday, al-Shabaab warned of a "long, gruesome war" unless Kenya withdrew its troops from Somalia, and threatened "another bloodbath".

entry.title: Militant group al-Shabab threatens more attacks on Kenya
Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
entry.summary: In a message directed at Kenyans, the al-Qaida aligned group said the raid on Garissa was revenge for Kenya's military presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
entry.summary:
The timing of the attack was embarrassing for Kenyatta, who a day earlier had berated Britain and Australia for issuing travel warnings for Kenya due to security threats.

Garissa Governor Nathif Jama said the region has a number of security "soft spots", including schools and hospitals, and asked for more boots on the ground in his county, which forms part of Kenya's porous 700km border with Somalia.

entry.title: Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
Three days of mourning as Kenya grapples with Garissa massacre
entry.summary: Kenyatta's comments will put more pressure on Kenya's Muslim community, who make up about 10 percent of the 44-million-strong population.

entry.title: Kenyatta says Garissa attackers 'embedded' in Kenya Muslim community
entry.summary: The attack at Garissa, which lies 120 miles from the Somali border, has put Kenya on high alert and spooked its Christian communities after reports the gunmen sought out Christian students while sparing some Muslims.

entry.title: Three days of mourning as Kenya grapples with Garissa massacre
entry.summary:
Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, where several resort towns cater mainly for Western tourists, police have deployed armed officers in major public buildings.

"Officers are everywhere both on the ground and in the air. We have two helicopters that will be patrolling the entire coastal area," Robert Kitur, police chief for Kenya's Indian Ocean coast region, told Reuters.

entry.title: Kenyaâ€™s revenge: Naked corpses paraded
entry.summary: POLICE have paraded the naked corpses of Somali al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabab gunmen who slaughtered almost 150 people in one of Kenya's worst massacres, hours after the militants threatened "another bloodbath".

entry.title: Kenya: Extremists vow more attacks; president responds
entry.summary:
Women look across as Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) soldiers arrive at a hospital to escort the bodies of the attackers to be put on public view, in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

A woman covers her mouth after going in to view the bodies of the alleged attackers, having been encouraged to do so by security guards, at the hospital mortuary in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya's president vows harsh action against Somali rebels
entry.summary: Members of the public run to get a glimpse as authorities display the bodies of the alleged attackers before about 2,000 people in a large open area in central Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya Survivor Found in School After Attack Killed 148
entry.summary: Survivor of the killings at Garissa University College Cynthia Cheroitich, 19, who was found on Saturday two days after the attack, drinks some milk in a hospital ward in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya: Survivor found in school attack which killed 148
entry.summary: Women go through the local papers of the news on Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Somali militants vow to turn Kenyan cities 'red with blood'
entry.summary: Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, police have put armed officers in major public buildings.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more bloody attacks against Kenya
entry.summary: The al Qaeda aligned group said the attack was retribution for Kenya's presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more bloody attacks against Kenya
entry.summary: In the message, directed at the Kenyan public, the group vowed a long and gruesome war, saying Kenya's cities will "run red with blood".

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more bloody attacks against Kenya
entry.summary: MOGADISHU (Reuters) - Somali militants on Saturday threatened to stage more bloody attacks on Kenya after the group's fighters killed nearly 150 people during an assault on a Kenyan university on Thursday.

entry.title: Pope decries persecution of Christians, including in Kenya
entry.summary: Pope Francis prays for persecuted Christians as Easter celebrations begin after Islamist militants killed at least 147 people in Kenya.

entry.title: Pope decries persecution of Christians, including in Kenya
entry.summary:
Rome: Pope Francis presided at two Good Friday services, praying for persecuted Christians a day after Islamist militants attacked a university in Kenya, killing at least 147 people.

In their attack on the university in Kenya on Thursday, al Shabaab militants initially killed indiscriminately but later freed some Muslims and targeted Christian students during a siege that lasted about 15 hours..

entry.title: Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary:
A victim of Thursday's university attack is assisted to a plane by medical staff prior to being airlifted to Nairobi, at the Garissa military airstrip, Garissa, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

Survivors and relatives gave other harrowing accounts of the siege by Islamic extremists as Kenya on Friday mourned the victims of the attack, the deadliest since the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi that killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Shock, defiance in Kenya after Shebab massacre 148 at university
entry.summary: The day-long siege of Garissa University in which 148 people, mostly students, were killed was Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, and the bloodiest ever by the Al-Qaeda-affiliated militants.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: Members of Kenya Defense Forces stand guard at the Garissa University College in Garissa, northeastern Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: The attack at Garissa University College happened six days after Britain advised "against all but essential travel" to parts of Kenya, including Garissa.

entry.title: Horror in Kenya: Somali militants massacre students
entry.summary: Medics help an injured person at Kenyatta national Hospital in Nairobi, Kenya, after an attack by gunmen at Garissa University College.

entry.title: Survivor of Deadly Kenya University Attack Says Gunmen Had Scouted Campus
entry.summary: In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa, victims of the worst attack in Kenya since the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy by al-Qaida which killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus

entry.summary: In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa.

entry.title: Kenya college attack survivor hid among dead
entry.summary: GARISSA, Kenya - The militants who slaughtered 147 people in a Kenyan school appeared to have planned extensively, even targeting a site where Christians had gone to pray, a survivor said Friday.

entry.title: Al-Shabab militants kill 147 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: Police identified a possible mastermind of the attack as Mohammed Mohamud, who is alleged to lead al-Shabab's cross-border raids into Kenya, and they posted a $220,000 bounty for him.

entry.title: Al-Shabab militants kill 147 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: The al-Qaida-linked group has been blamed for a series of attacks in Kenya, including the siege at the Westgate Mall in Nairobi in 2013 that killed 67 people, as well as other violence in the north.

entry.title: The Latest: Officials: 147 die in Kenya attack
entry.summary: Kenya's national disaster operations center and the interior minister say the attack by al-Shabab gunmen on a college campus has claimed 147 lives, besides four attackers who also died.

entry.title: Gunmen kill more than 70 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Al-Shabab gunmen stormed a university in northeastern Kenya at dawn Thursday, killing more than 70 people in the group's bloodiest attack in the East African country, officials said.

entry.title: The Latest: Death toll more than 70 in Kenya college attack
entry.summary: Kenyan police have offered a $220,000 bounty for Mohammed Mohamud, also known as Dulyadin alias Gamadhere whom they believe is the mastermind of the attack on a college in Garissa, in northeast Kenya.

entry.title: Over 70 dead as masked gunmen attack Garissa University: Kenya interior minister
entry.summary:
Also known by the names Dulyadin and Gamadhere, he was a teacher at an Islamic religious school, or madrassa, and claimed responsibility for a bus attack in Makka, Kenya, in November that killed 28 people.

In his speech to the country, he said he had directed the police chief to fast-track the training of 10,000 police recruits because Kenya has "suffered unnecessarily due to shortage of security personnel."

entry.title: Al-Shabaab Kenya attack: death toll rises to 70 - live updates
entry.summary: Kenyan Interior Minister Joseph Nkaissery says that more than 70 people have been killed in an attack by Somali-based Islamic extremists on a college in northeast Kenya.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary: Gunmen attacked a college campus in northeast Kenya early Thursday, opening fire in dormitories and killing at least 15 people and wounding 29 others, witnesses said.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary:
Kenyan police officers take cover outside the Garissa University College during an attack by gunmen in Garissa, Kenya, Thursday, April 2, 2015.

Students of the Garissa University College get out of a house where they seek refuge after fleeing from an attack by gunmen in Garissa, Kenya, Thursday, April 2, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya says 29 people wounded in attack on university, most with gunshot wounds
Gunmen kill two in dawn attack on Kenya university
entry.summary: "Gunmen forced their way into Garissa University by shooting at the guards manning the main gate at around 5:30 am," said Kenya Police Chief Joseph Boinet.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm university in Kenya
entry.summary:
Police and military surrounded the buildings and were trying to secure the area in eastern Kenya, police officer Musa Yego said.

Police statistics show that 312 people have been killed in al-Shabaab attacks in Kenya from 2012 to 2014.

entry.title: Gunmen attack Kenya university in 'fierce shootout'
entry.summary: Kenya's National Police Service said in a written statement that armed attackers forced their way onto the campus by shooting at guards, triggering a "fierce shootout" with police guarding student hostels.

entry.title: Police: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya, killing 2
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Gunmen attacked Garissa University College early Thursday, shooting indiscriminately in campus hostels, killing at least two people and wounding four others, police said.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya university
entry.summary: Heavy gunfire and explosions were heard and the stand-off was ongoing at the Garissa University College, the Kenya's Daily Nation newspaper and Capital FM radio station said.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya university
entry.summary: Al-Qaeda linked al-Shabaab has vowed to punish Kenya for sending troops into Somalia alongside African Union peacekeepers to fight the group.

entry.title: Gunmen storm Kenyan college campus in Garissa: media
entry.summary: Somali Islamist militant group al Shabaab has carried out several attacks in Garissa and across Kenya in the past, including the 2013 attack on an upscale shopping mall in the capital Nairobi.

entry.title: Police: Masked gunmen attack university in Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Police: Heavy gunfire reported as masked gunmen attack Garrisa university in Kenya's northeast.

entry.title: Police: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - A police official says masked gunmen have stormed a university campus in Garissa Town in eastern Kenya.

entry.title: Police: Masked gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya
Masked Gunmen Attack University In Kenya
entry.summary: Kenya's northern and eastern regions, which border Somalia, have been most affected by attacks blamed on al Shabaab Islamists from Somalia.

entry.title: Obama to make presidential trip to father's homeland Kenya
entry.summary: Barack Obama will make a long-awaited trip to Kenya later this year, visiting his father's homeland for the first time since becoming US president six years ago, the White House said Monday.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary: The elder Obama died more than 30 years ago, though the president has other family still living in Kenya.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary:
The White House says Obama will visit Kenya in July for the Global Entrepreneurship Summit, which brings together business leaders, international organizations and governments.

During a trip to other African countries last year, he said he was likely to visit Kenya before leaving the White House.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama will make his first trip as president to Kenya, the country of his father's birth.

Obama visited Kenya as a U.S. senator, but never as president.

The president's father came to the United States from Kenya for school and returned to his home country after his son's birth.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary:
The government-funded report found that Kenya's second and third presidents, Daniel Arap Moi and Mwai Kibaki, headed governments that were responsible for massacres, economic crimes and grand corruption, among other violations.

Kenya's state security agencies, particularly the police and army, have been the main perpetrators of human rights violations, including massacres, enforced disappearances, torture and sexual violence, the report said.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Kenya's president apologized on Thursday to the Kenyan people for past wrongs committed both by his government and past regimes.

Kenya's Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission report had recommended that the president apologize to the public within six month after receiving it.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for past wrongs by his government and previous regimes
entry.summary: The report names the president and his deputy as being among those suspected of planning and financing Kenya's 2007-08 postelection violence in which more than 1,000 people died.

entry.title: 'No blacks' Chinese restaurant shut down in Kenya
entry.summary: Reports said the restaurant's Chinese owners and managers had also been summoned by Kenya's immigration authorities.

entry.title: British Islamist in Kenya 'possessed bomb-making materials'
entry.summary: Materials recovered from the home of a British terrorism suspect in Kenya were capable of making explosives, a court in Mombasa heard Friday.

entry.title: Al-Shabab claim responsibility for 4 dead in Kenya
Al-Shabab claim responsibility for 4 dead in Kenya
entry.summary:
"The attack is part of a series of attacks targeting the Northern Frontier District region under Kenya's occupation," said al-Shabab's radio Andulus."The Mujahideen forces who carried out the attack safely returned to base."

Kenya's northern and eastern region border Somalia and a significant number of inhabitants there are Kenyan-Somalis.

Al-Shabab has been attacking Kenya since Kenyan troops were deployed to Somalia in Oct 2011 to fight the militants.

entry.title: Al-Shabab claim attack which killed 4 people, wounded 3 northern Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya - Somalia's al-Shabab Islamic extremists claimed responsibility Wednesday for an attack that killed four people in Kenya's volatile northern region, bringing to 12 the number of those killed by the militants since Friday.

entry.title: New Shebab attack in northeast Kenya kills four
entry.summary:
Four people died in a gun and grenade attack on Wajir town in northeast Kenya, the latest in a series of cross-border raids by Somalia's Shebab militants, officials said Wednesday.

The attack is the fourth in five days in Kenya's remote and increasingly lawless northeast, which borders war-torn Somalia.

entry.title: Islamic extremist group al-Shabab suspected in northern Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary:
Adan Duale, a Kenyan Somali who is majority leader in parliament, was quoted on the BBC Somali Service on Saturday telling al-Shabab to leave Kenya alone.

Kenya has experienced a string of attacks since it sent troops into Somalia in October 2011.

entry.title: Al-Shabab suspected in Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary:
"If you wish to, we shall send you elders, religious leaders and politicians. We shall come, tell us your whereabouts. Leave Kenya alone," Duale said in a statement that many in Kenya interpreted as a call for negotiations with al-Shabab.

But Duale said Sunday on his Twitter account that Kenya will never negotiate with "terrorists."

entry.title: Kenya Police: 3 people killed in attack on governor's convoy
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Islamic militants attacked a governor's convoy in north Kenya on Friday for the second time in five months, killing three people, a police official said.

entry.title: Kenya Police: 3 people killed in attack on governors convoy
entry.summary:
Al-Shabab, an Islamic extremist group, has vowed to inflict violent attacks on Kenya because it has contributed troops to the African Union force supporting the western-backed government in Somalia.

Hundreds of teachers in parts of northern Kenya that borders Somalia have refused to return to work, fearing attacks by the Islamic extremists despite government reassurance of increased security.

entry.title: Kenya: Businessmen, ex-officials charged for fraud and abuse of office
entry.summary: Al-Shabab extremists from Somalia have carried out 129 attacks in Kenya since Oct. 2011 saying its retribution for the Kenyan troop presence in Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory to deter elephant poachers
entry.summary: A Kenya Wildlife Service officer next to the pile of contraband ivory.

entry.title: Kenya torches 15 tonnes of illegal ivory in anti-poaching fight
entry.summary: Kenya has imposed longer jail terms and bigger fines for wildlife poaching and trafficking, saying poaching is harming tourism, a major earner of foreign exchange.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory in anti-poaching fight
entry.summary:
NAIROBI - Kenya burnt 15 tonnes of ivory on Tuesday and promised to destroy all of its stockpile this year, the latest step in its campaign against elephant poaching.

"As part of Kenya's continued policy to put ivory beyond economic use ... I will today burn 15 tonnes of ivory at this historic site in Nairobi National Park," President Uhuru Kenyatta said during a ceremony at the park.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Kenya's president set fire to 15 tons of elephant tusks during World Wildlife Day Tuesday to discourage poaching and trade in ivory.

Hamilton said Kenya has a long way to go before it can be clear of the poaching menace.

"We would like to tell the world to stop the trade in ivory because it is destroying our economy, our heritage, our environment," said Paul Udoto, a spokesman for the Kenya Wildlife Service.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
A firefighter controls the flames as 15 tons of elephant tusks are set on fire during an anti-poaching ceremony at Nairobi National Park in Nairobi, Kenya Tuesday, March 3, 2015.

The years 2011, 2012 and 2013 witnessed the highest levels of poaching since a poaching crisis in the 1980s, Kenya's Wildlife Service has said.
